questions.text: All are De Lancey's level 1 support except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

DeLancey classified pelvic support into three anatomical levels based on the location and function of fascial and ligamentous structures that support the uterus and vaginal walls.

Perineal muscle

  • This structure contributes to Level 3 support, not Level 1.
  • It supports the distal vagina and perineum, preventing perineal descent and gaping of the vaginal introitus.

Explanation of the Other Options:

Mackenrodt's ligament (Option A):

  • Also known as the cardinal ligament, it provides horizontal cervical support and is a key component of Level 1 support.

Uterosacral ligament (Option B):

  • Anchors the cervix and upper vagina to the sacrum; central to Level 1 support.

Infundibulopelvic ligament (Option D):

  • Although its main role is to carry ovarian vessels, it contributes some upper pelvic support and is functionally associated with Level 1 structures.

questions.text: All can lead to genital wall prolapse except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Genital prolapse refers to the descent of pelvic organs (e.g., uterus, vaginal walls, bladder, or rectum) due to weakening of the pelvic floor muscles, fascia, and ligaments. This results in protrusion of the vaginal or uterine structures, often presenting as a bulge, dragging sensation, or pelvic pressure.

Estrogen maintains the tone and integrity of pelvic muscles and connective tissues.High estrogen levels are protective, not causative, against genital prolapse.

In fact, hypoestrogenism (e.g., postmenopausal state) contributes to atrophy and weakening of pelvic supports, increasing the risk of prolapse.

questions.text: Upper two third of anterior vaginal wall prolapse leads to
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A cystocele refers to herniation of the urinary bladder into the anterior vaginal wall.It results from weakening of the pubocervical fascia, especially in the upper two-thirds of the anterior vaginal wall.

Common symptoms: feeling of bulge, urinary incontinence, frequency, or retention.

  • he anterior vaginal wall is closely related to the urinary bladder superiorly and the urethra inferiorly.
  • It can be divided into:
    • Upper two-thirds - closely associated with the bladder
    • Lower one-third - associated with the urethra

When support of the upper two-thirds is lost (due to childbirth, chronic straining, aging, or pelvic surgery), the bladder herniates into the vagina, forming a cystocele.


Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Urethrocele (Option B):

  • Involves prolapse of the urethra through the lower one-third of the anterior vaginal wall.
  • Typically associated with stress urinary incontinence.
  • Often seen in combination with cystocele (called cystourethrocele).

Enterocele (Option C):

  • A herniation of the pouch of Douglas (cul-de-sac) containing small intestine through the posterior vaginal wall, usually at the vault or apex (Level 1 support defect).
  • More common after hysterectomy.

Lax perineum (Option D):

  • Refers to a defect in Level 3 support, involving the perineal body and muscles.
  • Causes widening of the genital hiatus, may coexist with rectocele or uterine descent.
  • Not related to anterior wall defects.

questions.text: Stage 2 in POP-Q classification is when points A and B are at
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The POP-Q system quantifies pelvic organ prolapse using fixed reference points on the vaginal wall, measured in centimeters relative to the hymenal ring (which is defined as 0 cm):

  • Negative values: Above (proximal to) the hymen
  • Positive values: Below (distal to) the hymen

Key points:

  • Aa, Ba: Anterior vaginal wall
  • Ap, Bp: Posterior vaginal wall
  • C: Cervix or vaginal cuff (if hysterectomized)
  • D: Posterior fornix (if uterus is present)

Stage 2 includes prolapse that is just reaching or slightly beyond the hymenal ring.

  • The leading edge of the prolapse (point Ba, Bp, or C) lies within 1 cm above or below the hymen.
  • It is usually symptomatic and may present with a visible bulge or sensation of heaviness.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

  • Option A (-3 cm): Represents Stage 0 (normal position of vaginal walls)
  • Option B (< -1 cm): Reflects Stage 1 prolapse (mild descent, not reaching the hymen)
  • Option D (> +1 cm): Indicates Stage 3 or 4, depending on the extent beyond hymen

questions.text: All are the complications of vaginal prolapse except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Vaginal prolapse refers to the descent of pelvic organs through the vaginal canal due to weakening of the pelvic floor support. This leads to exposure of the mucosal surfaces and mechanical effects on adjacent structures.

Although chronic irritation from prolapse may cause keratinization or ulceration, there is no direct causation established between prolapse and malignancy.

Cervical and vaginal cancers are associated with HPV infection, immunosuppression, and poor genital hygiene, not with prolapse itself.

Explanation of the Incorrect Options

Keratinization (Option B):

  • Due to chronic exposure of the vaginal mucosa to air and mechanical friction, non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium undergoes keratinization.
  • This is a protective adaptation, but it can cause dryness, thickening, and irritation.

Decubitus ulcer (Option C):

  • Pressure and friction on the prolapsed vaginal wall can lead to ischemia and ulcer formation.
  • Often seen in advanced prolapse; may cause bleeding, infection, and hinder surgical repair.

Urinary tract infections (Option D):

  • Prolapse may cause urinary stasis, incomplete bladder emptying, and kinking of the urethra, predisposing to UTIs.
  • Recurrent infections are common in untreated cystoceles.

questions.text: A 30 years old multipara has uterine prolapse, the management of choice is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In a 30-year-old multiparous woman presenting with uterine prolapse, the management should aim at preserving the uterus (as she's still young) while also considering that she has likely completed her family. The most appropriate and balanced approach in such a case is Fothergill's repair with tubal ligation

Fothergill's repair, also known as the Manchester operation, is a uterine-sparing surgical procedure designed to correct uterine descent. It involves amputation of the elongated cervix, plication of the Mackenrodt's (cardinal) ligamentsanterior to the cervix to provide support, and reconstruction of the cervical canal. This procedure is particularly well-suited for younger women with uterine prolapse who wish to retain their uterus, either for psychological reasons or in rare cases where future fertility is still desired.

However, in a multiparous woman who has already had children and does not desire future fertility, combining Fothergill's repair with tubal ligation provides both prolapse correction and permanent contraception. The addition of tubal ligation ensures that future pregnancies, which could compromise the surgical repair or worsen the prolapse, are avoided.

This approach avoids the need for vaginal hysterectomy, which, while effective, is more invasive and generally reserved for older or postmenopausal women

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Fothergill's repair alone (Option A):

  • Suitable if future fertility is desired
  • In a multipara with completed family, tubal ligation should be combined, making this less complete than Option B

Sling operation (Option C):

  • Typically used in young nulliparous women where uterus must be preserved
  • More often done in congenital prolapse or women with no desire for hysterectomy and family not complete
  • Examples: Shirodkar's, Khanna's sling

Vaginal hysterectomy (Option D):

  • Standard for elderly or postmenopausal women
  • Not preferred in a 30-year-old unless uterus is severely damaged or other indications exist

questions.text: A lady with a prolapsed uterus after Fothergill's repair will complain of the following except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Fothergill's repair (also known as Manchester operation) is a uterus-sparing surgery performed for uterine prolapse, especially in young women who wish to preserve fertility. It involves:

  • Amputation of the cervix
  • Plication (tightening) of the cardinal ligaments (Mackenrodt's ligaments) anterior to the cervix
  • Repair of any associated cystocele or rectocele

After Fothergill's repair, pregnancy is possible, but the procedure can lead to certain obstetric complications due to the altered anatomy of the cervix.

Common complications include:

  • Cervical dystocia (Option B): Due to fibrosis and scarring from cervical amputation, the cervix may not dilate properly during labor.
  • Premature labour (Option C): Cervical incompetence or shortening from the surgery can lead to early labor.
  • Premature rupture of membranes (Option D): Cervical changes or infections due to prior surgery may predispose to early rupture.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, gravida 2 para 1, presents at 14 weeks of gestation with third-degree uterine prolapse. What is the best management approach in this case?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Ring pessary is a safe, non-invasive, and effective method to manage uterine prolapse during pregnancy.

It provides mechanical support to keep the prolapsed uterus in position and relieves symptoms like discomfort, vaginal pressure, and risk of cervical ulceration.

Especially in the second trimester, when the uterus begins to enlarge and becomes an abdominal organ, a pessary helps support this transition and prevents further descent.

It also helps avoid complications such as infection, preterm labor, and cervical injury.

Explanation of Incorrect options:

Sling surgery (Option A) is not appropriate during pregnancy. It involves surgically suspending the uterus to stronger ligaments or using synthetic materials. This kind of procedure poses significant risks, including bleeding, infection, preterm labor, or miscarriage. Such surgical management is typically considered only postpartum if conservative treatment fails.

Foot end elevation (Option B) may offer temporary relief by using gravity to help reduce the prolapsed uterus. While it can be a helpful adjunct in the early stages or when awaiting pessary fitting, it is not definitive management. It does not provide consistent support and cannot prevent the worsening of the prolapse as pregnancy advances.

No treatment (Option D) is an unsafe approach in a case of third-degree prolapse during pregnancy. Leaving it unaddressed increases the risk of serious complications, including infection, premature labor, cervical ulceration, and potential obstruction during delivery. Even if the patient is asymptomatic, close monitoring and at least mechanical support with a pessary are recommended.

questions.text: Most important structure preventing uterine prolapse is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cardinal ligament (also known as the transverse cervical ligament) is the most important supportive structure in preventing uterine prolapse. It extends from the lateral pelvic wall to the cervix and upper vagina. Its primary role is to provide horizontal support to the uterus and cervix, keeping the uterus centrally positioned in the pelvis.

This ligament contains dense connective tissue and is firmly anchored to the pelvic sidewalls. It is also the main structure clamped and ligated during Fothergill's (Manchester) operation and hysterectomy, showing its central role in uterine support.

In uterine prolapse, the cardinal ligament complex weakens or elongates, contributing significantly to the descent of the uterus. Hence, it is considered the key structure preventing uterine prolapse.

Explanation of Incorrect options:

Round ligament (Option A):
The round ligament helps maintain the anteverted position of the uterus but provides minimal support against uterine descent. It stretches during pregnancy but does not prevent prolapse. It is more of a positional stabilizer than a supportive one.

Broad ligament (Option B):
The broad ligament is a double fold of peritoneum that drapes over the uterus and supports uterine contents loosely. It contains vessels and nerves but has no significant mechanical support function. It does not prevent uterine prolapse.

Uterosacral ligament (Option D):
The uterosacral ligament pulls the cervix posteriorly and works in combination with the cardinal ligament to support the uterus. While it is important, its role is secondary to the cardinal ligament, especially in providing vertical support. It maintains uterine axis and prevents retroversion, but not prolapse as effectively.

questions.text: Indication of Manchester operation in prolapse:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Manchester operation (also known as Fothergill’s operation) is primarily indicated for young women, typically under 35 years of age, with second-degree uterine prolapse and cervical elongation, who have completed childbearing or are not planning more children soon. The operation aims to preserve the uterus while correcting the prolapse.

This uterus-sparing approach is suitable in women under 35, as they are often younger and may not prefer hysterectomy. Although not the best choice if future pregnancies are desired, it is commonly offered to young women with prolapsewho do not wish to undergo hysterectomy.

Explanation of Incorrect options:

Nulliparous (Option A):

Manchester operation is not recommended in nulliparous women. Since the procedure involves cervical amputation, it can lead to future infertility, cervical incompetence, or dystocia during labor. In women who have never conceived, conservative or suspension procedures are preferred.

Patient who wants child bearing function (Option C):

Though the uterus is preserved, Manchester operation is not ideal for women actively desiring future pregnancies. Cervical shortening increases the risk of cervical dystocia, preterm labor, or miscarriage. Fertility-preserving procedures like uterine sling surgeries are safer alternatives.

Congenital elongation of cervix (Option D):

This condition refers to cervical lengthening present without associated uterine descent. Manchester operation is not indicated here because it is meant to correct cervical elongation in the context of uterine prolapse. Isolated congenital elongation may require different approaches or observation.

questions.text: In which sling surgery a mersilene tape is sutured from anterior longitudinal ligament retroperitoneally on right side to back of cervix to behind sigmoid colon and psoas muscle to left anterior longitudinal ligament?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Shirodkar's sling procedure is a uterine suspension surgery used to treat uterine prolapse in young women who wish to preserve their fertility. It uses Mersilene tape (or fascia lata) to create a supportive sling that anchors the cervix to the anterior longitudinal ligament of the spine.

In this procedure:

  • A Mersilene tape is sutured to the posterior aspect of the cervix.
  • It is passed retroperitoneally along the right side, anchored to the anterior longitudinal ligament at the level of L4 vertebra.
  • The tape then crosses the pelvis behind the sigmoid colon and the psoas muscle.
  • It finally reaches the left anterior longitudinal ligament, completing a firm supportive sling.

This technique provides central and strong uterine support, and is extra-peritoneal, minimizing the risk of intra-abdominal complications. It's particularly beneficial in young women with uterine prolapse who want to avoid hysterectomy.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Purandare's sling (Option A):

This is a posterior sling procedure that uses rectus sheath fascia to support the uterus. The sling is placed behind the uterus and attached to the anterior abdominal wall. It is less physiological and provides anterior support, unlike the deep retroperitoneal path of the Shirodkar sling.

Khanna's sling (Option C):

This involves the use of a polypropylene mesh attached to the anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS) and passed through the broad ligament to support the uterus. It is a simpler, more superficial procedure, not involving passage behind the sigmoid colon or psoas.

Virkud's sling (Option D):

This is a modification of Purandare's sling, where the sling is passed through sacrospinous ligaments for better support. It does not involve anterior longitudinal ligament fixation or retroperitoneal tunneling across the pelvis.

questions.text: Most common complication of Purandare's sling surgery?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Purandare's sling surgery is a uterus-sparing anterior sling procedure used for uterine prolapse. It involves attaching a strip of rectus sheath or fascia lata from the anterior abdominal wall to the isthmus of the uterus, providing anterior support.

Because this sling only supports the uterus anteriorly, it does not provide adequate support to the posterior vaginal wall. As a result, the pouch of Douglas remains unsupported, predisposing the patient to posterior vaginal wall prolapse, specifically enterocele, which is the herniation of small bowel into the vaginal canal through the posterior fornix.

Hence, enterocele is the most common complication after Purandare's sling procedure.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Bowel obstruction (Option A):

This is not commonly associated with Purandare's sling. The procedure is extraperitoneal and uses superficial fascia, so the risk of direct bowel injury or obstruction is minimal.

Difficulty in cesarean section (Option B):

While this can be a concern in deep pelvic sling surgeries (e.g., Shirodkar's), it is rare in Purandare's sling, as the uterus is only anchored anteriorly and not fixed deep in the pelvis.

Retroversion (Option D):

Purandare's sling tends to pull the uterus anteriorly, which may actually correct retroversion. It does not causeretroversion. If anything, it may result in an exaggerated anteversion, but this is not a common complication.

questions.text: Transvaginal sacrospinous ligament fixation is done for
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Vault prolapse refers to the descent of the vaginal apex (vault), typically after a hysterectomy, where the uterus has been removed. It occurs due to loss of support from the uterosacral-cardinal ligament complex, leading to downward displacement of the vaginal cuff.

Sacrospinous ligament fixation (SSLF) is a commonly performed transvaginal procedure to correct vault prolapse. In this surgery:

  • The vaginal vault is sutured to the sacrospinous ligament, typically on the right side, to anchor and elevate the vault.
  • It restores vaginal length and axis, preventing further descent.
  • SSLF is minimally invasive, performed via the vaginal route, and avoids abdominal surgery.

It is one of the standard techniques for post-hysterectomy vault prolapse repair.

Explanation of incorrect options:

Vaginal prolapse (Option A): This is a vague term and may refer to uterine, vault, or vaginal wall prolapse. SSLF is specifically used for vault prolapse, not for general or anterior vaginal wall support.

Enterocele (Option B): Enterocele is a herniation of small bowel into the posterior vaginal wall. Though it may coexist with vault prolapse, it is treated primarily with posterior colporrhaphy, not sacrospinous fixation.

Retroverted uterus (Option D): A retroverted uterus is a normal anatomical variation and does not represent a prolapse. It typically requires no treatment unless symptomatic, and sacrospinous fixation has no role in correcting uterine version.
